Award.AwardTitle: Asymptotic behavior for dispersive and hyperbolic PDEs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Pusateri, 1265875)

The PI proposes to investigate the long-time behavior of solutions for some classes of dispersive and hyperbolic PDEs. The proposed research revolves in particular around three classes of problems. The first concerns the question of stability of flat interfaces for the irrotational free boundary Euler equations describing the motion of water waves. The second pertains to the study of the asymptotic behavior for nonlinear systems of mixed hyperbolic/dispersive type, such as the Maxwell-Schroedinger, Klein-Gordon-Zakharov, and Wave-Schroedinger systems. The third is related to singular limits over long intervals of time for point wise decaying solutions of some nonlinear hyperbolic PDEs. The PI's general aim is to prove, under certain conditions, global existence of solutions evolving from small Cauchy data. Furthermore, he aims to characterize the behavior of solutions at infinity and, in particular, answer the question of scattering, determining whether the global solutions constructed behave or not like linear ones for large times. A central theme of the proposed research will be the identification of the mechanisms determining at highest order the global regularity of solutions and the stability of certain equilibria. The PI expects some of the questions addressed to have highly non-trivial answers regarding the qualitative behavior of solutions for large times.

The equations under consideration describe a variety of physical phenomena such as fluid flows, quantum mechanics and plasma turbulence. Their relevance is widely recognized and supported by numerical and experimental evidence. Understanding the quantitative and qualitative properties of solutions, and their behavior over long periods of time, would be of importance for several research areas in the theoretical and applied sciences. For example, proving global-in-time stability of water waves models will improve our understanding of the motion of waves, such as those generated offshore on the surface of the deep ocean. It would also be relevant to numerical investigations and experiments aiming to understand how rogue waves are generated from apparently calm waters. Establishing mathematically rigorous stability results in some specific regimes would rule out some of their possible causes. Furthermore, proving that certain specific nonlinear asymptotic behaviors can occur in some of the equations considered, would reveal deeper connections with other fundamental models such as the nonlinear Schroedinger equation, which is ubiquitous in many branches of mathematics, physics, and engineering. The PI believes that solving the proposed problems would require substantial extensions of the current analytical methods, which may result in significant technical improvements of interest for the mathematics community at large. Finally, beyond pursuing his own projects, the PI will also be actively engaged in the dissemination of his research and will strongly promote collaborations among different groups within the international PDE community and researchers in related areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are used to describe a wide variety of phenomena in the physical world, from the motion of fluids and plasma, to the description of elementary particles, to the evolution of stars. The main  focus of this project has been the study of nonlinear PDEs describing the complex nature of the nonlinear interactions of waves, particles, fields... In particular, we have investigated the dynamics of various physical systems analyzing their evolution over large periods of time and trying to determine their asymptotic behavior.

Most of the proposed projects have been successfully pursued, and important advances have been made towards the long-term goals that were set forth in the proposal.

 

Open problems of interest to many groups of researchers in Analysis, PDEs and related areas, have been solved. Chief examples of these are results concerning the water waves equations, which are a system of PDEs describing the motion of an incompressible fluid separated from vacuum/air by a free moving interface, like waves on the surface of the ocean. More precisely, we provided the first proof of the existence of non-trivial global solutions for two dimensional gravity waves, showing the stability of a flat interface. We then obtained similar results in the case of capillary waves, that is, waves moving under the effects of surface tension (joint works with A. Ionescu). More recently we constructed global-in-time solutions for the full three dimensional water waves system under the influence of gravity and surface tension (joint works with Y. Deng, A. Ionescu and B. Pausader).

Several other important results have been obtained in the context of nonlinear dispersive and wave equations, in particular concerning the study of the long-time behavior, qualitative and quantitative properties of solutions, their decay to equilibrium, and their asymptotics. Examples here are studies on: the Boson Star equation, a semi-relativistic massive model from stellar dynamics; the Chern-Simons-Schrodinger equation (joint work with S. Oh), which is a non-relativistic gauge field theory in 1+2 dimensions arising in the study of several planar phenomena, such as high critical temperature superconductors; the stability of solitons - special solutions that keep their shape over time as they travel - for the modified Korteweg-de Vries equation, a classical model for the motion of long waves in a shallow canal  (joint work P. Germain and F. Rousset).

More recently we have also obtained results on the 1d nonlinear Schrodinger equation with a potential (joint work P. Germain and F. Rousset). This serves as a model for studying the asymptotic stability of special solutions, such as topological solitons and kinks, representing coherent states and particle-like objects in classical and quantum field theories.

The solutions of the problems studied in this project required the development of many new analytical tools and methods of broad interest. Among other things, these investigations led to the discovery of novel mechanisms for the long-time existence and asymptotic stability for solutions of fundamental physical world equations. These developments resulted in significant technical improvements of interest to researchers working in related subjects, such as harmonic analysis, general relativity, and dynamical systems. Connections to other areas of applied Mathematics, fluid dynamics, and Mathematical Physics have been made as well. As an example, the proof of global stability for the gravity-capillary water waves system in three dimensions has improved our understanding of the motion of waves and of the role played by surface tension in the long-time stability. Furthermore, our results on gravtiy waves provided remarkable connections to classical equations, such as the nonlinear Schrodinger equation, and to integrable systems, through the phenomenon of modified scattering. Results on nonlinear equations under the influence of external potentials have received interest from the mathematical physics community, and gave us the opportunity to begin interdisciplinary collaborations on open problems of interest in particle physics.

 

The project has also provided the P.I with multiple opportunities for training students and collaborating with mathematicians in the early stages of their careers. These activities included the supervision of an undergraduate thesis on the paradifferential analysis of the water waves system, collaborations with five graduate students on three separate research projects, and multiple collaborations with postdocs.

The P.I has been actively engaged in the dissemination of the outcomes of the project by giving specialized seminars, as well as colloquium talks aimed at general academic audiences, in many Universities in North America and Europe (on average on about ten occasions per year). The P.I also gave several lectures in larger international conferences, including workshops at the Clay Mathematical Institute (Oxford, UK), ICERM (Providence, RI), IHES (Paris, France), and BIRS (Banff, Canada).
